body: IN late September the final hull section of a new nuclear-powered attack submarine, the Connecticut, arrived at the Electric Boat shipyard in Groton, and was welded into place. Workers are now putting the final touches on a warship that will, for the first time in 75 years, bear the state's name on the open ocean. The submarine is to be christened
title: A Submarine Carries the Name Connecticut

body: The altar boy swaggered through the gyms of Brooklyn in a bomber jacket, intimidating tough guys with a ''ghetto stare'' he practiced in the mirror and a machine-gun rap that drowned out the knocking of his knees. Few knew that Gerard Papa had a Columbia law degree and lived at home with his mother. For more than 20 years, the bluff worked; he
title: A Coach Who Pushed Sees His Team Pushed Aside

body: FROM the Navy Yard in Williamsburg to the Army base at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn was a borough at war in late 1943. There seemed to be soldiers everywhere: local boys home on leave, others enjoying themselves before shipping out to Europe and thousands more in training in the New York area. Among them was a wide-eyed 20-year-old from a small town in
title: Dese, Dem and Dole

body: To the Editor: Your Aug. 7 news article on New Yorkers having to store trash for recycling fails to address the larger issue raised by reductions to the city's recycling program. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has committed himself to closing the Fresh Kills landfill and yet is undermining recycling, the city's only viable alternative to landfilling.
title: Don't Leave Brooklyn Out of Landfill Equation

body: To escape prosecution on a possible perjury charge, the former president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation has admitted to lying about the improper purchase of office furniture, according to sources close to the investigation. The former chief, Elizabeth Colon, was abruptly dismissed from the Navy Yard corporation in April amid
title: Deal Is Reached in Inquiry Of Ex-Navy Yard Chief

body: NEW YORK Grate Sparks Subway Fire A rusted Depression-era metal grate suspended above an East Side subway tunnel gave way and tumbled to the tracks, leading to electrical explosions and a fire that hampered service to much of Queens and Manhattan for nine hours and trapped dozens of riders in blinding smoke. Transit officials said the failure might
title: Metro Digest

body: Three months after the president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation was dismissed amid an investigation into an improper purchase of office furniture, a permanent chief has yet to be selected to head the 260-acre, city-owned industrial park. An interim chief, Marta Moczo-Santiago, was appointed by the corporation's board after the
title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;Three Months Later, Navy Yard Still Needs Captain for Long Haul

body: It all began in the summer of New York City's collective nervous breakdown, as was said at the time -- a panic attack set off by a soaring rate of random, often drug-fueled violence and a deepening fear that the city was spinning out of control. The murder rate for 1990 set a record: 2,245 killings. But the toll seemed especially irrational and
title: THE TRAIL OF 'THE ZODIAC': THE HISTORY;In a Jittery Summer, a Killer Surfaced

body: BY the middle of 1990, the complex set of approvals to map the streets and run the electricity and dig the sewers and build the parks were in place for a 10,000-apartment development, and Arverne -- the name taken from the surrounding neighborhood -- was ready to rise on the waterfront of the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens. But the recession hit, the
title: 80's Giant Dreams Facing 90's Economic Realities

body: New Yorkers love their superlatives. Not long ago, someone thought that the world's biggest garbage landfill, sprawling across 3,000 acres of Staten Island, could even serve as a tourist draw. But the Fresh Kills dump is an environmental disaster that politicians have long promised to shut down. The problem has been that no readily available
title: Shutting the Fresh Kills Dump

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki announced an agreement yesterday to close the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island by 2001, promising instead to find ways to export New York City's garbage and to increase recycling. Acknowledging that similar promises have been made and broken by past governors and mayors, Governor Pataki said
title: Despite Years of Broken Promises, Accord Vows to Close S.I. Landfill

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani named Marta Moczo-Santiago the new Juvenile Justice Commissioner yesterday, putting her in charge of the city's system for handling juvenile delinquents and offenders. Ms. Moczo-Santiago is a former deputy commissioner at the Department of Juvenile Justice whom the Mayor named in April to head the Brooklyn Navy Yard
title: New Appointee Will Oversee Juvenile Justice

body: Benjamin Eisenstadt, the innovative Brooklyn businessman who set Americans to shaking their sugar before sweetening their coffee and then shook up the entire sweetener industry as the developer of Sweet 'N Low, died on Monday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 89 and a major benefactor of Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. The
title: Benjamin Eisenstadt, 89, a Sweetener of Lives

body: The president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation was dismissed yesterday over concerns that an escalating investigation into her purchase of $30,000 in furniture was undermining her leadership of the nonprofit agency. The dismissal of Elizabeth Colon, ordered by the Navy Yard's directors, is effective immediately. The board's
title: Brooklyn Navy Yard Chief, Under Investigation, Is Dismissed

body: NEW YORK Giuliani Touts a Stadium Plan Mayor Giuliani has begun to offer the economic justification -- and along with it the political one -- for building the Yankees a new home on the West Side of Manhattan. He is touting a proposal to build a new stadium above the rail yards beside the Hudson River. [Page A1.] Police Plan Drug Offensive The New
title: METRO DIGEST

body: The City Council yesterday overwhelmingly approved a new solid-waste management plan that will speed up the city's timetable for recycling "mixed paper" and will require residents in all five boroughs to recycle items like cereal boxes, milk cartons and junk mail by the middle of next year. Mixed-paper recycling is now required only on Staten
title: Solid-Waste Management Plan Wins Council Approval

body: Gene Kelly, the dancer, actor, director and choreographer who brought a vigorous athleticism, casual grace and an earthy masculinity to the high romance of lavish Hollywood musicals, died yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 83. His longtime publicity agent, Warren Cowan, said Mr. Kelly had never fully recovered from strokes he
title: Gene Kelly, Dancer of Vigor and Grace, Dies

body: The Brooklyn Navy Yard has long dominated life in Northern Brooklyn, from the days when thousands built warships to the recent battles over a city plan to build a huge incinerator there. The Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation recently received $739,000 from the Mayor's Office to assess the state of the 260-acre plot and figure out how to
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DEVELOPMENT;Community Consensus for the Navy Yard: Yes on Housing, No on Trash

body: IT seems the simplest of props: footprints are painted on the floor, a baseball bat is suspended by wires, home plate is just below. On the wall behind looms a life-size photograph of Jackie Robinson. You, the visitor, put your feet in Robinson's footsteps and step up to the plate. You grasp the bat. Suddenly, the roar of the crowd materializes all
title: Brooklyn History, Inning by Inning
